entry.title: Getting started with SAP BTP
entry.content:
This end-to-end tutorial helps you set up your SAP BTP Trial and build a full-stack application using:

  • SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model)

  • SAP HANA Cloud
  • SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)
  • SAP Fiori Elements
  • Cloud Foundry Deployment
  • Approuter + XSUAA Authentication

This guide is ideal for students, beginners, and consultants who want to understand how real full-stack applications are built on SAP BTP.

Creating a SAP BTP Trial Account

Access SAP BTP Cockpit

Go to: https://account.hana.ondemand.com/

Click Create Account → This creates:

  • A Global Account

  • A Default Subaccount
  • Access to BTP Cockpit services like BAS, HANA Cloud, etc.

     

Understanding Global Account, Directories & Subaccounts

Global Account:

This is the root-level account that contains all subaccounts, users, quotas, and entitlements.

Directories

Directories help organize subaccounts logically such as:

  • Development

  • Testing
  • Production

How to create:
Account Explorer → Create → Directory

Subaccount

A Subaccount is where the actual development happens. We can:

  • Enable services

  • Deploy applications
  • Create destinations
  • Manage entitlements
  • Select region + environment

Steps:
Account Explorer → Create → Subaccount

Entitlements:

Entitlements are your service quotas — they define which services your subaccount can use (e.g., HANA Cloud, XSUAA, Destinations).

You can always allocate or modify entitlements for each subaccount.

Boosters — Automated Guided Configuration

Boosters help you set up complex scenarios with just a few clicks, such as:

  • SAP HANA Cloud

  • SAP Build Apps
  • SAP Build Process Automation
  • CAP + Fiori Full-stack setup

Navigate to:
Boosters → Start

Cloud Foundry: Spaces & Instances

Space

A space is a workspace inside Cloud Foundry used for:

  • Deploying apps

  • Managing services

 Instance

An instance is a running version of a service like:

  • Destination

  • XSUAA
  • HANA Cloud
  • HTML5 Apps Repository

 

Setting Up SAP HANA Cloud

Go to:
Subaccount → Services → Instances & Subscriptions
Select SAP HANA Cloud

If you face a permission error → assign the user:

In the left-hand panel, go to Security > Users

 SAP HANA Cloud Administrator role collection
Subaccount Admin

Mapping HANA Instance to Cloud Foundry

Mapping allows CAP HDI containers to deploy artifacts to HANA Cloud.

Instance → Actions → Manage Configuration
Click Sign in to Cloud Foundry → Add Mapping → Review → Save

Setting Up SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)

Create a Dev Space

Open BAS → Create Dev Space:

Full-Stack Cloud Application

Enable:

  • Workflow module
  • SAP HANA Tools
  • SAP HANA Performance Tools

Open the Dev Space once it turns RUNNING.

Building a CAP Project

Project Steps:

  • Open the workspace

  • Update mta.yaml file → Change database path ‘gen/db’ to ‘db’
  • Update package.json →Replace existing CDS code -
"cds": {
    "build": {
      "tasks": [
        {
          "for": "hana",
          "dest": "../db"
        },
        {
          "for": "node-cf"
        }
      ]
    },
    "requires": {
      "db": {
        "kind": "hana-cloud"
      }
    }
  • Install dependencies:
npm install
  • To get Additional files in db folder
npm install -g hana-cli
hana-cli createModule

Add CDS files - Right click on db folder - 

  • /db/e_learning.cds
namespace app.e_learning;
using { Language, managed } from '@sap/cds/common';

type string50 : String(50);

entity Categories {
    key id          : UUID;
    name            : string50;
    description     : String(100);
    Courses         : Association to many Courses on Courses.category=$self;
}

entity Courses : managed {
    key course_id   : UUID;
    course_name     : string50;
    price           : String(100);
    Language        : Language;
    category        : Association to Categories;
}
  • /srv/eLearning_srv.cds 
using app.e_learning from '../db/e_learning';

service eLearning {
  entity Categories as projection on e_learning.Categories;
  entity Courses as projection on e_learning.Courses;
}

Build Project

cds build

Deploying to SAP HANA Cloud

  • Go to DB module → Deploy

  • Open HDI container → load data

  • Import using SAP HANA Database Explorer

Now, right click on table and click on Open Data

Running the App Locally

cds bind -2 e_Learning-db:SharedDevKey
npm install
cds watch --profile hybrid

Deployment to Cloud Foundry

mbt build

Deploy

cf deploy mta_archives/e_Learning_1.0.0.mtar

Adding Approuter + XSUAA for Authentication

Approuter

Provides a single entry point for your application and handles routing & authentication.

Create using BAS:
Right-click → Create MTA Module from Template → Approuter

XSUAA

Authentication is different from authorization

Authentication - Ensures the user is valid and can access the system.

Authorization - Checks the scopes/roles

Adds OAuth2.0-based authentication & authorization.

cds add xsuaa
npm install

This generates:

  • xs-security.json
  • Required scopes/roles

Generating a Fiori Application:

Using templates:
Right-click → Create MTA Module from Template → SAP Fiori App

Run: 

cds watch

entry.title: Securing SAP Business AI: A Multi-Layer Architecture for Enterprise Trust
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as the Head of Cybersecurity and Compliance in SEA and is recognized as a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP) by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). He supports strategic customer engagements on cybersecurity, data privacy, multi-cloud security architecture, contractual assurance, and compliance.)

Introduction

Enterprise AI has moved decisively from experimentation to strategic necessity. Organizations today are no longer debating whether to adopt AI, but how to deploy it securely, responsibly, and at scale without breaking existing business processes, security models, or compliance obligations.

SAP Business AI represents SAP’s enterprise-first approach to this challenge. Rather than treating AI as a standalone capability, SAP embeds intelligence directly into business applications and executes AI-driven actions within the same architectural boundaries that govern core enterprise workloads. This means AI operates with full awareness of business context, user identity, authorization, data sensitivity, and regulatory constraints.

This blog provides an end-to-end architectural walkthrough of SAP Business AI using a layered reference architecture. It explains how Joule serves as the unified AI interaction layer, how agentic execution patterns enable AI to plan and act within controlled boundaries, how identity and principal propagation enforce enterprise authorization, and how security, privacy, and governance are built into every stage of the AI lifecycle.

Multi-Layered Architecture

The SAP Business AI architecture is designed as a layered system, where each layer has a distinct responsibility while remaining tightly integrated with adjacent layers. This separation of concerns allows enterprises to adopt AI capabilities incrementally, without compromising identity, security, or governance controls.

Layer 1: Experience Layer

The experience layer represents the entry point for business users and developers interacting with AI capabilities. It includes familiar SAP user touchpoints such as SAP Fiori, SAP Build Work Zone, Joule Co-Pilot, and SAP Mobile Start. This layer is responsible for presenting AI capabilities in a way that feels native to SAP applications rather than as a separate AI tool.

Joule sits prominently in this layer as the conversational interface, translating user intent into structured requests that can be processed by the AI runtime. SAP Build also appears in this layer, reflecting how custom applications and extensions can expose AI-driven experiences using the same architectural foundation. Importantly, this layer does not execute AI logic itself. It captures intent and context and hands off responsibility to the orchestration layer below.

 

Component

Purpose

SAP Fiori

Enterprise web applications that surface AI-assisted insights and actions

SAP Build Work Zone

Unified digital workplace that exposes AI-driven tasks and recommendations

Joule Co-Pilot

Conversational AI interface that captures user intent across SAP applications

SAP Mobile Start

Mobile-first access to AI-assisted workflows and insights

SAP Build

Low-code and no-code tools to design AI-enabled user experiences

Layer 2: Orchestration Layer - Coordinating AI Execution

The orchestration layer is where SAP Business AI moves beyond simple prompt-and-response interactions. This layer coordinates how AI requests are prepared, governed, and executed. It includes AI Core as the execution backbone, SAP Generative AI Hub (via SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad) as the controlled access point to foundation models, and supporting capabilities such as prompt templating, data masking, content filtering, and agent memory.

This layer is responsible for shaping requests before they ever reach a model. Prompts are templated to enforce consistency, sensitive data is masked where required, and content filters are applied to ensure responsible usage. Agent memory allows the system to maintain conversational and task context across multiple steps, enabling more advanced, agentic execution patterns. By centralizing orchestration here, SAP ensures that AI behavior is predictable, repeatable, and policy aware.

 

Component

Purpose

AI Core

Runtime for executing AI workloads and agentic execution loops under policy control

Generative AI Hub

Centralized, harmonized access to foundation models with enterprise governance

Prompt Templating

Standardizes prompt structure to ensure consistency, control, and predictable model behavior

Data Masking

Detects and masks sensitive data before it is sent to models

Content Filter (Input)

Evaluates and filters user input to enforce responsible AI usage

Content Filter (Output)

Screens model responses to prevent unsafe or non-compliant output

Agent Memory

Session Context Management (Agent Memory Pattern) – Maintains conversational and task context across multi-step interactions

Harmonized API Access

Provides a consistent interface for invoking models and AI capabilities across providers

Layer 3: Grounding Layer - Anchoring AI in Enterprise Context

The grounding layer ensures that AI responses are based on enterprise reality rather than generic model knowledge. This layer is responsible for context and evidence retrieval and connects AI execution to authoritative business data and documents.

As shown in the architecture, grounding sources include SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere, document repositories, knowledge graphs, and the SAP HANA Vector Engine. SAP Integration Suite also plays a role in accessing distributed enterprise systems. Together, these components allow AI to retrieve relevant business context using semantic and vector-based techniques, ensuring that responses are accurate, explainable, and aligned with enterprise data models.

This layer is fundamental to trust. By grounding AI outputs in traceable enterprise sources, SAP Business AI enables explainability and reduces the risk of hallucinations or contextually incorrect actions.

 

Grounding Source

Use Case

Context and Evidence Retrieval

Real-time retrieval of relevant business context and supporting evidence

SAP Knowledge Graph

Semantic relationships between business entities and concepts

SAP Business Data Cloud

Unified business data foundation across SAP applications

SAP Datasphere

Analytical and data warehousing context for AI grounding

Document Grounding

Retrieval of unstructured business documents such as contracts and PDFs

SAP HANA Cloud Vector Engine

Vector-based semantic search and similarity matching

SAP Integration Suite

Real-time access to distributed and third-party systems

Layer 4:  Execution Layer - Turning Insight into Action

The execution layer is where AI-driven decisions are translated into concrete business actions. This includes SAP APIs, Joule Skills, function calling, Model Context Protocol servers, agent-to-agent interactions, and SAP Build Process Automation workflows.

This layer enables AI to move from recommendation to execution, whether that means calling an SAP API, triggering a workflow, or coordinating actions across systems. Importantly, execution is not autonomous in an uncontrolled sense. Tool access and actions are constrained by identity, authorization, and runtime policies inherited from the underlying platform. This ensures that AI can act, but only within the same boundaries that apply to human users and technical integrations.

 

Execution Mechanism

Purpose

SAP APIs

Invoke business operations in SAP applications such as S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and other SAP services

Joule Skills

Encapsulate reusable business actions that can be triggered through Joule

Function Calling

Enable structured invocation of predefined actions based on AI decisions

Model Context Protocol (MCP) Servers

Open standard providing standardized context and tool interfaces for AI-driven execution (governed via AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX)

Agent-to-Agent (A2A) Interaction

Industry protocol enabling coordinated actions across multiple specialized agents

SAP Build Process Automation (BPA)

Trigger workflows and business processes requiring orchestration or approvals

Layer 5: Governance Layer - Sustaining Trust Across the AI Lifecycle

The governance layer spans the entire architecture and ensures that SAP Business AI remains compliant, auditable, and manageable over time. It includes capabilities such as AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX, Joule Studio, AI Launchpad, model registries, data privacy integration, and audit log services.

This layer governs both design-time and runtime aspects of AI. Before deployment, use cases, risks, and models are reviewed and approved. During runtime, actions are logged, monitored, and subject to human-in-the-loop controls where required. After deployment, lifecycle management, regulatory alignment, auditability, and traceability ensure that AI systems continue to meet enterprise and regulatory expectations.

 

Governance Component

Purpose

AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX

Central visibility and governance of AI agents and their relationships

Joule Studio

Design-time configuration and management of Joule skills and AI interactions

AI Launchpad

Model lifecycle management, versioning, and approval workflows

Model Registry

Central inventory of approved AI models and configurations

Data Privacy Integration

Enforcement of data protection and privacy controls across AI usage

Audit Log Service

Centralized logging of AI actions for auditability and compliance

Human-in-the-Loop Controls

Approval gates for sensitive or high-risk AI-driven actions

Cross-Cutting Controls: Security, Privacy, and Observability

Running alongside all layers are cross-cutting enterprise controls covering identity and access, data protection, content safety, and observability. Authentication, principal propagation, OAuth-based access, encryption, tenant isolation, audit logging, and monitoring are not tied to a single layer but are enforced consistently across the entire stack.

This design reinforces a core principle of SAP Business AI: SAP Business AI is designed to extend existing enterprise security controls rather than introduce parallel security models. Identity, authorization, and audit principles that govern SAP applications are applied consistently to AI-driven interactions.

Agentic AI Execution Flow: From User Intent to Governed Business Action

This diagram illustrates broadly how SAP Business AI executes agentic workflows in a controlled, enterprise-grade manner. The flow begins with the user interacting through Joule in the experience layer. Joule captures intent and context but does not execute logic itself. Instead, it forwards the request to the agent orchestration layer running on SAP BTP, where the execution lifecycle is coordinated under policy control.

At the core of this flow is SAP AI Core, which manages the agent runtime and enforces execution boundaries. Large language model calls are routed through SAP GenAI Hub, while short-term memory maintains session context and intermediate reasoning. Grounding retrieves enterprise-relevant context and evidence from long-term memory sources such as SAP Datasphere, SAP S/4HANA data, documents, and the SAP HANA Vector Engine. Based on this grounded context, the agent proposes the next action. Crucially, all actions pass through control execution code that enforces authorization, audit logging, and human confirmation where required. Only then are SAP APIs, workflows, or automations invoked. Results are returned through the orchestration layer back to Joule, accompanied by explanations and supporting evidence.

This execution model ensures that SAP Business AI can reason and act, but never outside established enterprise controls. AI-driven actions follow the same identity, authorization, and audit principles as human-initiated actions, making the system predictable, explainable, and trustworthy at scale.

 

Flow Element

Responsibility

User

Initiates the request or question through an SAP application

Joule (Experience Layer)

Captures user intent and presents AI-driven responses

Agent Orchestration

Coordinates the agent workflow and execution sequence

AI Core

Executes the agent runtime with policy enforcement

LLM Call (via GenAI Hub)

Performs language reasoning using governed model access

Short-Term Memory

Maintains session context and intermediate results

Grounding

Retrieves enterprise context and Top-K evidence for accuracy

Long-Term Memory

Provides access to business data, documents, and vectors

Agent Proposes Tool Call

Determines the next business action to execute

Control Execution Code

Enforces authorization, audit logging, and approvals

Tool Invocation & Action

Executes SAP APIs, workflows, or automations

Results Returned to Joule

Delivers explained outcomes with supporting evidence

Key Considerations for Adoption 

While SAP Business AI provides a comprehensive architectural foundation, successful adoption requires deliberate planning:

Start with Identity, Not AI: Before enabling Joule or deploying agents, ensure your SAP BTP identity and access management foundation is solid. Principal propagation, role-based authorization, and audit logging must already be in place AI capabilities inherit these controls rather than introducing new ones.

Grounding Quality Determines AI Quality: AI outputs are only as trustworthy as the data they are grounded in. Prioritize data quality, semantic consistency, and governance in SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Datasphere before scaling AI use cases across the enterprise.

Govern Agents Early, Not Later: The proliferation of AI agents SAP-delivered, custom-built, and third-party can quickly become unmanageable. Establish visibility and governance through the AI Agent Hub in SAP LeanIX from day one. Retrofitting governance after deployment is significantly harder.

Plan for Human-in-the-Loop by Design: Not every AI-driven action should be autonomous. Identify high-risk processes, such as financial approvals or compliance-sensitive workflows, and design explicit human checkpoints using SAP Build Process Automation before deploying agentic capabilities.

Real World Complexity

The layered architecture presented in this blog is a conceptual framework synthesized from SAP product capabilities and architectural patterns. It is intended to help readers understand how the components fit together, not to represent an official SAP reference architecture.

In practice, enterprise landscapes are rarely this clean. Organizations typically face:

Hybrid environments where on-premises SAP S/4HANA, RISE with SAP Cloud ERP Private, and GROW with SAP S/4HANA cloud, public edition, SaaS cloud deployments, requiring careful consideration of where AI processing occurs and how data flows across trust boundaries.

Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) scenarios where organizations deploy custom or third-party models in SAP AI Core, introducing additional customer responsibility for model security, bias testing, and lifecycle management.

Multi-cloud and non-SAP integrations where AI agents must access data from AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, or third-party SaaS applications each introducing distinct authentication models, data residency constraints, and compliance requirements.

Regulatory variability where AI governance requirements differ significantly across jurisdictions (for example, the EU AI Act and sector-specific regulations), requiring flexible policy enforcement rather than one-size-fits-all controls. This framework provides a starting point, but each enterprise must map it to its specific landscape, risk tolerance, and regulatory context. For a deeper look at trust boundaries and secure data flows, see Securing SAP Business AI Architectures.

Conclusion

SAP Business AI shows that enterprise-scale AI does not require compromising on security, privacy, or governance. By structuring AI as a layered architecture across experience, orchestration, grounding, execution, and governance, SAP embeds intelligence directly into business processes while ensuring that every AI interaction operates within established identity, authorization, and audit controls. Joule captures user intent, orchestration governs how AI requests are shaped and executed, grounding anchors decisions in enterprise data, and execution translates insight into action only within approved boundaries, while governance ensures lifecycle oversight and regulatory alignment. The result is an AI operating model that allows systems to reason and act with confidence, transparency, and control, moving AI from experimentation into a trusted, operational capability for the enterprise

References:

Securing SAP Business AI Architecture: Trust Boundaries and Secure Data Flows

SAP AI Core

Generative AI Hub in AI Core

Grounding with AI Driven Architecture

entry.title: SAP Cloud Connector Subaccount Certificate Automated Renewal has arrived!!
entry.content:
I wrote a Blog post some time ago (back in 2020!) in the #SAPCommunity about SAP BTP Cloud Connectivity issues due to expired certificates. The BTP Subaccount certificates needed to be regularly renewed - every 12 months in fact and it could only be carried out manually. While SAP provided information to customers about upcoming renewals (in later releases of the SAP Cloud Connector) with messages and Alerts within the SAP Cloud Connector - certificates that expired caused no end of trouble. This still causes a lot of issues for customers today. 

The previous blog post has reached over 60K views so you can see a fair number of customers experienced this issue. https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-cloud-connectivity-issues-due-to-expired-certificate/ba-p/13431648

The goods news is - SAP released an update to the SAP Cloud Connector application to automate these renewals. Yes - you have read this correctly!  The update 2.18.0 was released in March 2025 and I only recently found out that this was possible. So if you have a previous version of the SAP Cloud Connector running then schedule an upgrade ASAP. I also wrote instructions for upgrading the Cloud Connector for Linux and Windows here -> https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/upgrading-the-sap-cloud-connector-for-linux-os/ba-p/13338502 and https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/upgrading-the-sap-cloud-connector-for-windows-os/ba-p/13314729

To automate the Subaccount certificate renewal process multiple steps are required. This involves the SAP Cloud Connector as well as the relevant BTP subaccount. SAP note 3632133 covers the steps required to automate the Subaccount certificate renewal but I will cover this now. Here are the steps to automate renewal of Subaccount certificates so you don't have to worry about this again! 

  1. To enable automatic renewal in the SAP Cloud Connector. 
    Make sure when setting up Subaccount connectivity within the SAP Cloud Connector to toggle the [Auto Renewal] and set to ON. For subaccounts that are already set up just Edit the connection. 

2. To enable Auto Renewal in SAP BTP Cockpit:

  1. Log in to the SAP BTP Cockpit;
  2. Go to the respective Subaccount > Connectivity > "Cloud Connectors";
  3. Enable the "Allow Automatic Subaccount Certificate Refresh" toggle.

     

    As per the note, this is how the renewal works. 
     

    How Renewal Works

    • The renewal is triggered n + 7 days before certificate expiry, where n is the alert threshold (configurable in Observation Configuration -> Alerting);
    • If the renewal attempt fails, it is retried every 12 hours; If not successful within 7 days, the automatic renewal is cancelled.
    • No user credentials are involved in the automatic renewal of a BTP subaccount certificate. The authentication is handled by the currently valid subaccount certificate, provided that an administrator has enabled the auto-renewal feature for the subaccount on the BTP side too.

So, if the above instructions are followed you should not experience issues with Cloud connectivity again! 

The other good news is that this was submitted as an improvement request via the Customer influence engagement portal. In retrospect I wrote a blog post about it but did not submit a customer engagement initiative request to make an improvement but good to see others did. 54 others also voted for it. 5 years is also too long for this to be delivered given the amount of issues this caused for a lot of the customers I work with on a daily basis but glad that SAP has delivered this now. 

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/251489/?section=sectionDetails

Overall, I am really happy that SAP has delivered this functionality and I really hope customers plan to do upgrades to the SAP Cloud Connector to take advantage of this update ASAP. 

As always, thanks for reading and hopefully this helps!

  • Customize themes to mirror your customer’s brand identity

Content is adapted from internal SAP training and tailored specifically for partners, across roles—from consultants and designers to architects and developers.

If you’re looking to confidently extend today’s intelligent apps and prepare to build your own in SAP Business Data Cloud, this session is for you.

entry.title: Digital Transformation. View of an Enterprise Architect - Conway's Law
entry.content:
#GenerativeArt

 

Out of the Ivory Tower: Architecture, Organization, and the Reality of SAP Transformations

Many SAP transformations today do not fail because of technology. SAP S/4HANA, cloud architectures, and modern integration platforms are mature and powerful. Yet in practice, end-to-end processes often remain slow and inefficient.

The root cause is frequently not the system itself, but the organization that designs, operates, and evolves it.

 

When SAP Architecture Meets Organizational Silos

In many enterprises, SAP organizations have historically been structured around technical modules such as SD, MM, or FI. While these modules are technically connected through document flows, they are often organizationally separated.

This leads to familiar challenges:

  • High coordination effort across team boundaries.

  • Fragmented ownership along end-to-end processes.

  • Long lead times despite modern platforms.

As we discussed in Part 2 of this series, breaking down these organizational silos is one of the critical success factors for any digital transformation project. Without addressing these structural barriers, even the most advanced SAP S/4HANA migration or BTP implementation will struggle to deliver its full business value.

As a result, architecture becomes a reflection of organizational reality rather than a driver of innovation. If the organization thinks in silos, the system will operate in silos—regardless of the technology used.

 

Conway’s Law: Relevant in Everyday Practice

This pattern can be explained by Conway’s Law:
Systems inevitably mirror the communication and decision structures of the organizations that design them.

For SAP customers, this means that as long as organizations are aligned around technical components, architectures will follow the same structure—regardless of how advanced the underlying technology is. Agile methods alone do not change this as long as structural dependencies remain.

 

A Realistic Perspective on Organizational Change

Especially in large, established SAP organizations, one thing is clear:
Breaking down organizational silos is difficult and often not fully achievable.

Governance models, reporting lines, and historically grown responsibilities impose real constraints. A radical organizational redesign is therefore rarely feasible in the short term.

 

Why Awareness Still Makes a Difference

The key benefit already starts with awareness of the relationship between organization and architecture:

  • dependencies become visible earlier
  • architectural decisions are assessed more realistically
  • interfaces are understood as organizational, not just technical, challenges

Even without major reorganization, this awareness enables targeted improvements—for example, clearer end-to-end ownership for critical initiatives or more deliberate team setups where it matters most.

 

Conclusion

SAP architecture does not emerge in an ivory tower. It is always shaped by the organizational context in which it is created.
Those who understand and consider Conway’s Law make better architectural decisions—even when organizational silos cannot be fully removed.

Architecture is organizational design.

 

What Does This Mean for Your SAP Transformation?

Taking a conscious look at organizational structures, responsibilities, and communication paths can significantly improve the effectiveness of architectural decisions. Not every organization needs to be redesigned—but every transformation benefits from thinking about architecture and organization together.

 

Common thread of this blog series:

  1. Introduction 
  2. Tasks of an Enterprise Architect 
  3. Success Factors for Digital Transformation Projects 
  4. Help of an Enterprise-Architecture-Framework 
  5. Steps and Tips 
  6. Artificial Intelligence Meets Enterprise Architecture
  7. Conway’s Law

 

 

Reference:

Hohmann, M.; Wagner, D.: Architecture Is Organizational Design, iX – Magazine for Professional Information Technology, Issue 1/2026.

entry.title: From Automation to Agentic Ops: MCP Servers in SAP Automation Pilot
entry.content:
Nowadays, Ops teams are under increasing pressure to act faster, automate more, and collaborate with AI-driven assistants, all of that without compromising control, security, or reliability. As landscapes grow more complex, the challenge is no longer whether to automate, but how to make automation easily consumable by teammates and AI agents alike.

With tasks-specific MCP servers in SAP Automation Pilot, SAP introduces a powerful way to expose operational capabilities in a structured, manageable, and agent-friendly manner.

Typical use cases include SAP BTP operations such as Cloud Foundry Apps and SAP HANA Cloud checks, validations, diagnostics and remediations; SAP cTMS scenarios like transport validation or execution; incident management, etc. Beyond these examples, MCP Servers remain fully flexible as they can be shaped around any operational context where repeatable, governed actions are needed. This allows teams to start with well-known SAP-specific automations and gradually expand into custom, landscape-specific scenarios, relevant to their own needs.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers allow selected automations and content from SAP Automation Pilot to be exposed as tools. Instead of developing MCP servers by writing code or learning complex libraries, we are using the low-code/no-code capabilities of Automation Pilot, to deliver AI agents based on the needs and expectations of our Ops teams.

Why This Matters for Ops Teams

Incident handling, health checks, remediation, or maintenance activities all require different sets of actions depending on the situation and real-time systems’ state. Scenario-specific MCP servers reflect this reality by allowing Ops teams to group and expose only the automations relevant to a particular operational context. The result is an interaction model which is safe and secure for both humans and AI agents.

Because MCP servers are created using SAP Automation Pilot’s low-code / no-code capabilities, Ops teams can adapt quickly to new scenarios without writing custom APIs or services. Operational knowledge stays close to the teams who best understand their own use cases and IT resources and the agent is provided with precise tools proven to work instead of hard to assemble nuts & bolts.

From Automation to Agentic Operations

By exposing SAP Automation Pilot commands through MCP servers, operational actions become first-class capabilities that agents can consume dynamically.

This enables agentic interactions across many use cases, for example:

  • Agents can detect issues and trigger remediations;
  • DevOps and SRE teams can interact conversationally with agents;
  • Incident response becomes faster and more consistent;

Instead of navigating through multiple tools or help documents, the automations in agentic AI scenarios can be executed instantly, which dramatically reduces resolution time and manual effort.
At the same time, governance is built in. Only approved and selected automations are exposed, inputs are controlled, and every execution is auditable. This makes MCP servers suitable not just for experimentation, but for enterprise-scale production operations.

Once scenario-specific MCP servers are set up, they can be integrated seamlessly with various agent-based solutions, including also Cline and Joule (note: MCP server integration with Joule is already delivered, for more information, consult this blogpost: Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!).

This approach allows agents to move beyond recommendations and into real operational action without duplicating logic or skipping controls. Of course, SAP Automation Pilot remains the execution engine.

Learn More

If you would like to explore MCP servers in more detail or start using them in your own landscapes, please check out the SAP.Automation Pilot official documentation which provides further insights:

  • MCP Server Overview;
  • Managing MCP Servers;
  • Integrating SAP Automation Pilot with AI Agents;

Tasks-specific MCP servers mark an important step in the evolution from automated operations to AI agent-driven operations. If you have comments, ideas for scenarios, or topics you would like to explore further, feel free to leave a comment — your feedback is very welcome.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q4-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
Happy New Year and cheers to a sustainable year ahead! As we kick off 2026, I’m back with my quarterly blog series about the latest innovations and highlights in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Multi-Impact Categories
  • Streamlined Energy Management
  • Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections
  • Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide
  • BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Additional Information

 

Multi-Impact Categories

One of the most significant innovations this quarter is the introduction of multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, moving the product beyond carbon. Built on the same ERP-driven data foundation, governance model, and auditability, the latest updates extend the calculation engine to cover additional environmental impact categories. This lets you monitor a broader spectrum of environmental pressures without changing the way you integrate data or run calculations.

Think of multi-impact categories as different lenses on how your operations affect the Earth system. Aligned with planetary boundaries, they translate the data you already have into indicators for climate and other dimensions like land use, biosphere integrity, and biogeochemical flows. That means you can see where improvements in one area risk shifting burdens elsewhere – and manage those trade-offs with real numbers.

This matters for reporting because one consistent dataset can now serve multiple frameworks (e.g., CSRD, SBTi FLAG), reducing parallel tools and strengthening credibility with synchronized, audit-ready figures for sustainability, finance, and controlling. But this also matters for decision-making because placing multi‑impact indicators alongside financial and operational KPIs brings sustainability into core business steering. A richer picture of environmental pressure helps identify where reductions also improve efficiency, resilience, and brand value – and where hidden risks accumulate. This supports a shift from compliance‑driven reporting to performance‑driven management, where sustainability becomes a source of competitiveness and innovation.

Importantly, nothing changes in how you run the system. You still reuse ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre‑delivered factors, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that the same setup now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so your existing data and methods serve a growing list of corporate and product requirements – without extra integrations or parallel logic.

Footprint Results with additional Impact Categories

To learn more about this innovation, its business rationale, and how it supports your reporting requirements, check out my deep dive blog post: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. It also includes a step-by-step walkthrough of the overall workflow and the enhanced apps. For complete documentation and technical details, visit SAP Help: Calculating Footprints for Different Impact Categories.

We will also publish additional blog posts in the SAP Community, explaining in detail how you can map the multi-impact calculation results to various reporting requirements. Stay tuned!

 

Streamlined Energy Management

Managing energy data for footprint calculations has often been repetitive and time-consuming. Previously, you had to enter the same energy data and meter readings multiple times for different calculation variants, making workflows cumbersome and prone to errors. This complexity increased further when handling periodic meter readings and energy bills across multiple locations.

With the latest release, we’ve simplified this process significantly: For all newly created footprint calculations, energy bills and meter readings are now managed separately from the footprint inventory using two new types of GHG data forms. This means you can collect periodic energy data via the Record GHG Data app and reuse it across multiple calculations without redundant entries. Data maintenance is now independent of calculation variants, saving time and improving consistency.

We’ve also introduced more flexibility: you can calculate energy-related footprints based on energy sources only, without the need for an energy flow model, which is a major advantage for Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations. The user experience has been improved in the Calculate Footprints app as well, with data readings displayed directly on the first page of the inventory for quick access.

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and what has changed in the existing apps. For the full documentation, see Maintain Energy Bills and Meter Readings Using GHG Data Forms on SAP Help.

To use the new approach, start by preparing your footprint inventory scope. In the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app, activate form-based data collection for energy bills and meter readings. If you plan to use meter readings in your energy flow model, make sure to include Direct Emissions and Energy Consumptions under Value Chain Steps. For energy bills, this step isn’t required.

Define Footprint Inventory Scope with Form-Based Data Collection

Next, configure your energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. When creating an energy source, choose Enter Energy Bills if you want to manage consumption through the Energy Bills form, or Use Meter Readings and Planned Consumptions for meter-based data. Meters themselves are created in the Manage Locations app and must be assigned to the relevant plants. If you include meters in your energy flow model, they need to be in place before creating the footprint inventory.

With the scope and energy sources ready, create GHG data collections for the relevant plants and periods in the Manage GHG Data Collections app. Then, record your periodic energy data in the Record GHG Data app. You can enter values directly in the UI. Alternatively, you can download the template for offline editing and mass upload, or you can use the enhanced API for automating data entry and connecting smart meters – see the following chapter for details. Validation checks help ensure consistency, for example by flagging deviations greater than 30% from previous readings.

Record Meter Readings in GHG Data Form

Finally, run your calculation in the Calculate Footprints app. Newly created inventories no longer show separate tabs for energy bills and meter readings – instead, these values are maintained in the GHG data forms, and the Data Readiness section provides an overview of form status and associated models.

Calculate Footprints: Data Readiness

 

Mass Upload and API Enhancements for GHG Data Collections

Managing GHG data across multiple locations and form types can be a challenge, especially when dealing with large datasets. That’s why we’re introducing a powerful new capability, allowing mass upload for GHG data forms. You can now upload different types of forms – such as energy bills, meter readings, business activities, and waste data – across locations using a single template in the Record GHG Data and Manage GHG Data Collections apps. The template includes tabs for each form type, making it easy to consolidate and manage data efficiently without repetitive manual entry. For all details, check SAP Help: Working with GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

To take automation even further, the GHG Data Forms API has been enhanced with new endpoints and parameters for mass updates. This means you can retrieve and update forms programmatically, integrate with external systems, and even connect smart meters or IoT devices directly. Check out the API on SAP Business Accelerator Hub: GHG Data Forms.

These improvements reduce manual effort, increase accuracy, and save time. They’re also addressing several of the most requested features on SAP Influence.

 

Emission Factor Management & AI-Mapping Enhancements

High‑quality emission factors are the backbone of accurate and audit‑ready footprint results. The broader and better your factor library, the fewer workarounds you need, the faster you can onboard, and the more confidently you can answer customer and regulatory requests. Last quarter, we’ve expanded the default datasets, improved import templates and governance, and refined AI‑assisted mapping – so you can source, structure, and apply factors with less manual effort and higher precision.

With this release, the Manage Emission Factors app expands its default dataset substantially. We’ve added two new source packages and refreshed an existing one to broaden coverage and improve alignment with logistics and fuel methodologies. Newly added are:

  • GLEC Framework (Smart Freight Centre): Harmonized logistics factors across road, rail, air, ocean/inland waterways, and parcel/last‑mile; coverage for fuels and energy (TTW/WTT), logistics sites and equipment (warehousing, refrigeration, handling), plus rules for distance, allocation, and data quality aligned with ISO 14083.
  • German Environment Agency (Umweltbundesamt, UBA): Factors for fossil fuels including natural gas, hard coal, lignite, heating oils, diesel, gasoline, LPG, and more.

In addition, the UK DEFRA packages have been updated and now include the full set of emission factors. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data on SAP Help.

To make onboarding and governance smoother, and to align with the latest features, we’ve updated the import templates in the Manage Emission Factors app. The simple template (v3) and the LCA template (v5) now support impact categories beyond Climate Change, including the selection of an LCIA method and its characterization factor per dataset – so you can manage multi‑impact content consistently. In the Dataset Sources tab, you can add a source URL to the dataset for traceability, and unit validation has been tightened via the Dimensions column. We also streamlined context fields by adding a drop-down list to the Boundary column and moving it to the Emission Dataset tab to keep dataset‑level semantics in one place. For all changes, visit SAP Help: Emission Factors Data.

With the Custom Datasets feature in the Manage Emission Factor app, you can assemble component datasets into a single, composite dataset to derive an overall emission factor when a product or activity’s direct factor is unknown – leveraging known emissions of its parts to enable accurate footprint calculations. Now, those custom datasets also support multi-impact categories, so you can use it also for emission factors beyond climate change. For more information, see Creating Custom Datasets and Emission Factors on SAP Help.

Custom Dataset with Multi-Impact Emission Factors

We’ve also refined the AI-assisted emission factor mapping in the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app. This powerful feature suggests mappings between products (or product groups) from your ERP system and emission factors from LCA databases. A new option, Show Enhanced Footprint Suggestions, is enabled by default and shifts similarity scores to prioritize commodity code first, then text similarity, then country/region. This enhances mapping precision where commodity codes are available. If your ERP master data or LCA packages lack commodity codes, you can switch the option off to revert to text‑matching. Exact matches are elevated when product names and dataset names align and commodity codes are consistent (or both absent), even if descriptions are missing. To reduce false negatives, AI no longer pre‑filters by unit convertibility and you’ll only be blocked at release if unit conversions are missing in product master data. And for categories with sparse activity‑based data, AI now includes spend‑based factors when they rank among the top 10 suggestions. For all details, check SAP Help: Using AI to Map Emission Factors to Purchased Products and Product Groups.

Refined AI-assisted Emission Factor Mapping with Enhanced Footprint Suggestions

 

Other Release Highlights

To help you better understand your transport network at a glance, we added map visualizations for locations and transport routes across key apps. In the Manage Locations app, you can view locations on an interactive map along with details such as address, geocoordinates, postal code, and country or region. The Manage Transport Activities app now also provides a map-based view of generated routes and legs, helping you visualize transport flows more intuitively. On top of that, the Manage Transport Activities and Calculate Transport Footprints apps include an enhanced quick view for locations with an embedded map display. This means you can access location details and see them on a map instantly, streamlining your workflow and saving time.

Visualization of Transport Route and Legs

In my previous blog post, I introduced the Source Input Items feature in the Manage Footprint Results app that gives granular visibility into the inputs driving product emissions to identify hotspots and guide targeted decarbonization actions. We now enhanced this feature with the ability to generate source input items for cyclical calculations. This makes footprint analysis more comprehensive, especially for products calculated based on cyclical processes. On SAP Help, you find more information about source input items: Viewing the Footprint Results, and examples on cycle calculations: Calculating Cycles.

Another update improves data handling and coverage in the Import Business Transactions app: You can now add business transaction data to supplement imported records, with clear tracking of imported and added entries. New columns – Imported Records, Added Records, and Entry Method – provide transparency on how data enters the system, ensuring complete coverage for footprint calculations. The consolidated data (imported and added records) is then used to calculate footprints. For details, see Import Business Transactions, and for more information about business transactions' behavior, see Business Transactions Types on SAP Help.

Finally, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is now available in two additional regions: Europe (Frankfurt) and Brazil (São Paulo), both on AWS. This expansion supports customers operating in these regions with improved availability and compliance.

 

Enablement Updates: Webinar, Learning Journey & Scenario Guide

To make it easier for you to adopt the latest capabilities, we’ve expanded our enablement portfolio with new content and updates across multiple channels. Together with BearingPoint, we hosted a webinar that gives an overall introduction of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and also takes a closer look at multi-impact categories and what they mean for your sustainability strategy. Supported by a system demo, the session explains how these new dimensions help you move beyond carbon to a more holistic view of environmental performance. If you missed it, you can watch the full recording here:

We’ve also updated the Learning Journey Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations. A new unit now explains how to calculate GHG Scope 3.4 emissions using the ERP-centric transport footprint calculation capabilities introduced last year. This addition is particularly valuable for organizations looking to leverage existing ERP data for transport-related emissions without building parallel processes. It’s a practical guide to help you understand how these capabilities fit into your overall footprint model and reporting requirements.

In addition, we also published a new Scenario Guide that includes detailed process steps for calculating Scope 3.4 emissions based on data already available in your ERP systems: Process 8 – Calculating Scope 3.4 Emissions Using Business Transaction Data.

These enablement updates are designed to make adoption easier and faster, so you can focus on turning sustainability data into actionable insights. Whether you prefer learning through webinars, structured journeys, or detailed guides, we’ve got you covered.

 

BASF Coatings’ Journey with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Recently, I joined the Inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud Podcast to discuss sustainability and share real-world examples of how our solutions create impact. A highlight was my conversation with Maximilian Bauer from BASF Coatings, who explained how they use SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to tackle the complexity of sustainability in their business.

BASF Coatings operates in a highly dynamic environment, producing thousands of product variations with every color shade counting as a new product. This creates massive data challenges when calculating footprints. With SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, BASF Coatings can now:

  • Scale and automate carbon footprint calculations for hundreds of thousands of products.
  • Integrate seamlessly into existing systems, embedding sustainability into daily operations.
  • Gain actionable insights to offer more sustainable products and make data-driven decisions.

As Maximilian Bauer said: “You can only improve what you can measure – and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management offers us exactly this.”

Looking ahead, BASF Coatings is moving beyond carbon to multi-impact footprints, covering categories like abiotic resource depletion to ensure responsible use of finite resources. They’re also scaling innovations such as biomass balance and ChemCycling®, replacing fossil-based raw materials with renewable or recycled alternatives. These steps position BASF to meet growing global demand for sustainable products and stay ahead of regulatory expectations.

BASF Coatings’ journey illustrates why we’re evolving SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: from carbon-only to multi-impact sustainability footprints, enabling companies to manage risk, cost, and growth across multiple environmental dimensions – all embedded in core business processes.

In the podcast, I also shared our broader vision: embedding sustainability into business processes, leveraging a single trusted data foundation, and using AI to make sustainability intelligent and scalable. By expanding beyond carbon toward multiple impact categories, we help businesses move from compliance to competitive advantage.

Listen to the full episode on Apple Podcast or Spotify.

 

Additional Information

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. entry.title: Archiving B2B Messages from SAP Integration Suite in CMIS Repository
entry.content:
Co - Author: @patricia_torres 

Introduction

In today’s interconnected business landscape, B2B and EDI message exchanges form the backbone of critical business processes, including order management, invoicing, and logistics. These messages often carry legally binding information and must be handled with care. Archiving them within the B2B Capabilities of SAP Integration Suite is not just a best practice it’s a necessity. It ensures compliance with regulatory requirements, provides full traceability for audits, and safeguards data integrity. Beyond compliance, archiving helps maintain system performance by offloading historical data, while also supporting disaster recovery strategies. SAP Integration Suite provides built-in archiving capabilities that allow organizations to store B2B messages and related data in external Content Management Interoperability Services (CMIS) repositories.

This blog introduces the new archiving functionality in B2B Capabilities, explaining how it enhances security, efficiency, and compliance for your integration scenarios.

What is B2B Message Archiving?

B2B message archiving automatically saves your business transaction data from SAP Integration Suite to an external Content Management System (CMIS Repository) that supports the CMIS V1.1 protocol. This includes:

  • EDI messages (like invoices, purchase orders)
  • Message processing logs
  • Transaction details and metadata
  • Business document attachments

The system compresses each B2B transaction into a ZIP file and stores it in the CMIS Repository Reference.

Why Use CMIS Repository?

CMIS (Content Management Interoperability Services) is a standard protocol that allows different content management systems to work together (Reference).

Using CMIS for archiving provides several benefits:

  • Vendor Independence: Works with various content management systems
  • Standardized Access: Uses common APIs across different platforms
  • Scalability: Can handle large volumes of archived data

Setting Up B2B Message Archiving

Step 1: Prepare Your CMIS Repository

First, you need a CMIS-V1.1 compliant repository. Popular options include:

  • SAP Document Management Service on BTP
  • OpenText Core Archive for SAP Solutions
  • Other third-party CMIS systems

For demonstration purposes, I have installed the CMIS workbench referring to the blog.

Step 2: Configure the Destination

To enable B2B message archiving, you must configure a destination in SAP BTP that points to your CMIS compliant repository. This destination acts as the secure connection between SAP Integration Suite and the external storage system.

For General B2B Archiving, you can reuse the existing destination already configured for MPL archiving, as both message logs and payloads share the same repository.

For Dedicated B2B Archiving, set up a separate destination to maintain independent retention policies, authorization concepts, and access controls specifically for interchange payloads.

Correct destination setup is essential for compliance, security, and seamless archiving processes. The following section describes how to create and configure this destination in the SAP BTP cockpit:

  • Destination Name: CloudIntegration_LogArchive
  • URL: Your CMIS repository browser binding URL
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials (recommended)
  • Additional Property: RepositoryId = your repository ID

For Dedicated B2B Archiving:

  • Destination Name: CloudIntegration_B2BArchive

Step 3: Enable Archiving

Use the SAP Integration Suite APIs to activate archiving Reference:

  1. Call the activation API: /api/v1/activateB2BArchivingConfiguration

First get the access token using /oauth/token?grant_type=client_credentials and setting client id and client secret as Basic Authentication

 

Use this access token as Authorization Bearer token to activate B2B archiving.

 

  1. Select what you want to archive by going to Agreements under Trading Partner Management capability

Enabling Archiving in TPAs

Activating archiving for Trading Partner Agreements (TPAs) and their associated Business Transaction Activities is straightforward. You simply select the agreement and choose the transaction you want to archive. For each transaction, you can specify whether to archive the source data, the target data, or both. The archiving option is available under the Interchange Settings, making the configuration quick and intuitive.

What Gets Archived?

With CMIS based archiving, B2B message archiving is fully integrated with B2B Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite. All business-relevant data visible in the B2B Monitor, including interchange details, transaction status, partner identifiers, timestamps, and associated metadata, is securely persisted in the CMIS repository. In short, the archive provides a complete snapshot of the transaction context, ensuring full traceability and compliance.

For more details, refer to the official SAP Help documentation (Reference). The following will be archived:

Standard Fields:

  • Transaction status and processing details
  • Partner information
  • Message creation and completion times
  • Document types and directions

Custom Search Fields:

  • Up to 10 custom search attributes
  • Business-specific metadata
  • Custom transaction identifiers

File Format:

  • Each transaction becomes a ZIP file
  • File name format: Business_Document_Data_Content<Interchange ID>.zip
  • Contains all message payloads and metadata

Monitoring and Accessing Archived Data

Once archiving is enabled, archived B2B messages can be easily monitored and verified. The process is fully integrated with B2B Monitoring, where you can check the archiving status of interchanges using standard filters. For deeper inspection, you can connect to the CMIS repository using the Apache Chemistry CMIS Workbench. This free tool allows you to browse folders and download archived files, including both source and target payloads if configured in the Trading Partner Agreement. Together, B2B Monitoring and CMIS access provide transparent and convenient access to archived data.

Using CMIS Workbench

The Apache Chemistry CMIS Workbench is a free tool for viewing archived data:

  1. Download and install CMIS Workbench (Reference)
  2. Connect using your repository URL and authentication
  3. Browse folders to find archived messages – how to query in CMIS (Reference)

I have connected to the CMIS workbench to check the archived messages.

Downloaded the highlighted file.

Both source and target files are archived because I have checked to archive both source and target files in the Agreement.

Archived or Archiving Pending Messages can be checked in B2B Monitoring using the filter as below.

Important Considerations

Before you begin configuring B2B archiving, consider the following operational constraints and technical prerequisites that may impact your setup. Understanding these factors upfront will help you avoid surprises and ensure a smooth implementation. The following sections outline key limitations and system requirements you should review carefully.

Limitations:

  • Archiving job runs once a day and can’t be monitored directly in Integration UI
  • The scheduler runs once a day at a specific time (if needed it is possible to create a ticket to change that time)
  • Currently only completed and canceled messages are archived (failed messages must be manually canceled in B2B monitoring for archiving)
  • No automatic retry for failed archives
  • Archives are sent in single transactions
  • Requires proper authentication setup

System Requirements:

  • CMIS 1.1 compatible repository
  • Proper network connectivity
  • Sufficient storage space in target repository

Best Practices

  1. Test Your Setup: Use CMIS Workbench to verify archives are being created correctly
  2. Monitor Regularly: Check archiving status through the Integration Suite monitoring tools
  3. Plan Storage: Estimate storage needs based on message volume and retention requirements
  4. Security: Use OAuth2 authentication for better security

Conclusion

Archiving B2B messages to CMIS repositories provides a robust and scalable approach to long-term data retention. With SAP Integration Suite, archiving can be enabled easily, even at the level of individual Trading Partner Agreements, while remaining fully integrated with B2B Monitoring. This ensures that all relevant business data and metadata are preserved, offering full traceability and reliable access for compliance, auditing, and analysis.

By leveraging CMIS compliant repositories, organizations benefit from flexibility, scalability, and vendor independence for their enterprise content management needs. Following the recommended configuration steps and best practices helps ensure a secure, reliable, and future-ready archiving setup.

And stay tuned! Our next blog will cover how to retrieve archived messages efficiently so that you can make the most of your archived data.

entry.title: SAP ECC vs S/4HANA Integration Capabilities: A Practical Guide for Integration Architects
entry.content:
SAP System Exposure: The Complete Integration Capability Guide for ECC & S/4HANA

1. INTRODUCTION

When I'm asked to integrate an external system with SAP, the first question isn't "which tool should I use?" It's "what can SAP actually expose?"

After few years working across SAP ECC and S/4HANA landscapes with Integration Suite, I've learned that understanding what's available in your SAP system is just as critical as knowing how to integrate it. Yet most integration guides skip this foundation and jump straight to implementation.

This is the reference guide, it maps every integration capability available in SAP ECC and S/4HANA On-Premises systems, explains when to use each protocol, and provides the checklists you need to prepare your systems for Integration Suite connectivity.

What You'll Learn:

  • Complete inventory of integration capabilities in ECC vs. S/4HANA
  • RFC/BAPI, IDoc, OData, SOAP, and file interface fundamentals
  • Protocol comparison matrix with use case recommendations.
  • System preparation checklists for production readiness
  • Integration architecture patterns
  • Decision framework for choosing the right protocol.

Who This Is For:

  • Integration consultants working with SAP landscapes.
  • Solution architects designing SAP integrations.
  • Developers building connections to SAP systems.
  • Functional consultants exploring integration possibilities.
  • Anyone planning Integration Suite implementations.

Let's start with what SAP can actually give us.

 

2. SAP ECC INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

SAP ECC has been the backbone of enterprise operations for decades. While it lacks some modern REST/OData capabilities, it provides robust, battle-tested integration interfaces that still power thousands of integrations today.

2.1 RFC (Remote Function Call) & BAPIs

RFC is SAP's proprietary protocol for synchronous communication between systems. BAPIs (Business Application Programming Interfaces) are standardized RFCs that provide access to SAP business objects and processes.

Key Characteristics:

  • Synchronous: Call and wait for response
  • Transactional: Can commit or rollback
  • Type-safe: Strongly typed parameters.
  • Widely available: Broad range of reusable standard BAPIs in ECC

Common BAPIs You'll Use:

BAPI Name

Purpose

Use Case

BAPI_PO_CREATE1

Create Purchase Order

External procurement systems posting POs

BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE

Post Goods Movement

Warehouse systems updating inventory

BAPI_MATERIAL_GETDETAIL

Get Material Master

E-commerce platforms fetching product data

BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST

Post Financial Document

External systems creating FI documents

BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2

Create Sales Order

CRM systems posting orders to SAP

BAPI_CUSTOMER_GETDETAIL

Get Customer Master

External apps accessing customer data

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SE37 (Function Builder)
  • Discovery: Search pattern "BAPI_*"
  • Testing: SE37 → Test/Execute
  • Authentication: RFC destination in SM59

When to Use RFCs/BAPIs:

Use When:

  • You need real-time, synchronous responses
  • Transaction integrity is critical (commit/rollback)
  • Complex business logic required
  • Creating or updating SAP documents
  • Reading data with complex selection criteria

Avoid When:

  • Processing large data volumes (use IDoc instead)
  • No immediate response needed (use IDoc/async)
  • Simple CRUD on standard entities (use OData in S/4HANA)
  • Performance is more important than transaction integrity.

 Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Purchase Order Creation from Web Portal

Business Context:
Manufacturing company has external procurement portal where buyers create purchase requests. Once approved, these need to become POs in SAP ECC instantly.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Custom web portal (Node.js/React)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • BAPI: BAPI_PO_CREATE1
  • Frequency: Real-time (on PR approval)
  • Volume: 50-100 POs per day

Process Flow:

2.2 IDoc (Intermediate Document)

IDoc (Intermediate Document) is SAP’s standard asynchronous integration mechanism.
It is designed for high-volume, reliable, loosely coupled data exchange between SAP and external systems.

An IDoc is:

  • Self-contained
  • Status-driven
  • Processed independently of user interaction

This makes IDocs ideal for batch integrations, master data replication, and guaranteed delivery scenarios.

Key Characteristics:

  • Asynchronous: Fire-and-forget or guaranteed delivery
  • Bulk-friendly: Efficient for large volumes
  • Loosely coupled: Systems don't need to be online simultaneously
  • Status-tracked: Built-in monitoring (WE02, WE05)

IDoc Structure:

Common IDoc Types:

IDoc Type

Message Type

Purpose

Direction

ORDERS05

ORDERS

Purchase Orders

Outbound/Inbound

INVOIC02

INVOIC

Invoices

Outbound

Outbound

DESADV

WMMBXY

Outbound

CREMAS03

CREMAS

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction WE30 (IDoc Type Development)
  • Partner Setup: WE20 (Partner Profiles)
  • Port Config: WE21 (Port Definition)
  • Testing: WE19 (Test Tool)
  • Monitoring: WE02 (IDoc Display), WE05 (IDoc List)
  • Triggering: Message Control, Change Pointers, IDOC_OUTPUT_* FMs

When to Use IDocs:

Use When:

  • High-volume data transfer (thousands of records)
  • Asynchronous processing acceptable
  • Standard SAP business documents (PO, Invoice, etc.)
  • Batch processing requirements.
  • Need for guaranteed delivery with retry.
  • Master data replication

Avoid When:

  • Real-time response required immediately
  • Complex transformations needed
  • Non-standard data structures
  • Simple CRUD operations (overkill)

Integration Patterns:

Outbound (ECC → External):

Inbound (External → ECC):

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Nightly Material Master Sync to Data Warehouse

Company needs to send all material master changes from ECC to external data warehouse every night for reporting and analytics.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Target: External Data Warehouse (Snowflake)
  • IDoc Type: MATMAS05
  • Frequency: Nightly batch (2 AM)
  • Volume: 5,000-10,000 materials per night

 End-to-End IDoc Asynchronous Integration Flow

  1. Material master records are created or updated in SAP ECC throughout the day (MM01/MM02).
  2. Change pointers capture only relevant delta changes for the MATMAS message type.
  3. At 2:00 AM, the BD21 batch job executes during off-peak hours.
  4. The system reads accumulated change pointers.
  5. A MATMAS05 IDoc is generated for each changed material.
  6. IDocs are sent via partner profile WAREHOUSE using an HTTP port.
  7. SAP CPI receives the IDoc XML through the IDoc adapter.
  8. CPI parses the hierarchical IDoc structure.
  9. Business data is transformed into a target JSON format.
  10. Records are grouped into batches of 1,000 for optimized processing.
  11. CPI posts each batch to the Snowflake bulk API.
  12. On success, IDocs are updated to status 53 (Posted).
  13. On failure, IDocs move to 51 (Error) and are retried in the next batch cycle.
  14. A consolidated processing report is emailed to the data team at 3:00 AM.

2.3 SOAP Web Services

SAP ECC exposes business functionality as SOAP-based web services using the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR).
These services are WSDL-driven, XML-based, and follow a strict request–response contract over HTTP/HTTPS.

SOAP services are widely used in legacy enterprise landscapes, especially where Java or .NET middleware already exists.

Key Characteristics:

  • Standards-based: WSDL, SOAP 1.1/1.2, WS-* standards
  • Synchronous: Request-response pattern
  • Platform-agnostic: Any SOAP client can consume
  • Structured: XSD-defined schemas

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SOAMANAGER (Service Administration)
  • Development: SPROXY (Proxy Development)
  • Types:
    • Provider Services (ECC exposes to external)
    • Consumer Services (ECC consumes from external)

When to Use SOAP:

Use When:

  • External system requires SOAP/WSDL
  • Enterprise service repository already defined.
  • Need WS-Security features.
  • Cross-platform integration with Java/.NET systems

Avoid When:

  • Modern REST/JSON preferred (not natively supported in ECC)
  • Performance is critical (SOAP overhead)
  • Simple operations (BAPI or IDoc simpler)

Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Legacy Java Middleware Posting Financial Documents

Existing Java-based middleware system (10 years old) collects invoice data from multiple subsidiaries and needs to post consolidated financial documents to ECC.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Java middleware (Spring Boot)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Service: FinancialDocumentCreate (Enterprise Service)
  • Frequency: Real-time as invoices arrive
  • Volume: 200-300 documents per day

Process Flow:

  1. Java app collects invoice from subsidiaries.
  2. Validates and enriches data.
  3. Builds SOAP XML per WSDL specification.
  4. Sends SOAP request to CPI endpoint.
  5. CPI routes to ECC SOAMANAGER
  6. Enterprise service validates structure.
  7. Calls backend BAPI for FI posting.
  8. Document posted, accounting entries created.
  9. Returns FI document number in SOAP response.
  10. Java app stores document number for reference.

2.4 File Interfaces

File interfaces are one of the oldest and most reliable integration mechanisms in SAP ECC, designed for scheduled, high-volume, non-real-time data exchange.
Data is exchanged using physical files that are picked up, processed, and archived in batch cycles.

This pattern is still widely used for:

  • Vendor uploads
  • Price lists
  • Mass master data changes
  • One-time or recurring migrations

File Formats:

  • Flat files (fixed width, delimited)
  • CSV/Excel
  • XML
  • Custom formats

Technical Approaches:

  • Output: Report programs, BDC, LSMW
  • Input: Batch Input (BDC), Direct Input, BAPI calls

When to Use Files:

Use When:

  • Batch processing windows.
  • Large data migrations
  • Legacy system integration
  • Offline scenarios

Avoid When:

  • Real-time requirements
  • Frequent small transactions
  • Complex error handling needs.

Example Scenario: Nightly Vendor Price Upload (CSV)

The procurement team receives daily price updates from multiple vendors.
Each vendor uploads a CSV file containing updated material prices, which must be reflected in SAP ECC before business hours.

Technical Setup

  • Source: Vendor SFTP servers
  • Integration Layer: SAP CPI
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • File Type: CSV
  • Schedule: Nightly (4:00 AM)
  • Volume: ~50 files, 10,000–15,000 records

Process Flow (Clear & Sequential)

  1. Vendors upload CSV price files to the SFTP server between 1:00–3:00 AM
  2. At 4:00 AM, SAP CPI scheduler triggers the batch job
  3. CPI connects to SFTP and downloads all available files
  4. For each file, CPI:
    • Identifies the vendor from the file name
    • Parses the CSV line by line
    • Validates mandatory fields and price values
  5. For each valid record:
    • CPI calls BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA
    • Updates the vendor price / info record
  6. Processing continues even if individual records fail
  7. CPI writes:
    • Success entries to the success log
    • Failed records to the error log with reason
  8. Processed files are archived to /archive
  9. A summary report is generated
  10. Email notification is sent to the procurement team

WHAT SAP ECC CANNOT DO (WITHOUT WORKAROUNDS)

ECC is powerful for traditional integration, but modern patterns require custom work. Understanding this shapes your architecture strategy.

NO NATIVE REST/ODATA APIS

ECC doesn't provide REST APIs out of the box. You can build them, but not easily:

Workaround Options:

  • NetWeaver Gateway add-on (SEGW)
  • ICF HTTP handlers (IF_HTTP_EXTENSION)
  • Custom ABAP REST wrappers
  • SOAP-to-REST via CPI

LIMITED EVENT-DRIVEN CAPABILITIES

ECC has event-like features, but not modern event streaming:

What You Get:

  • Change pointers (batch-oriented)
  • Workflow events (tightly coupled)
  • IDoc triggers (application-specific)

What You Don't Get:

  • Publish/subscribe architecture
  • Multiple independent subscribers
  • Event replay
  • True decoupling

Impact: Adding a new event consumer requires ECC configuration changes. Not cloud-native.

Why This Works:

  • ECC does what it's designed for: business logic.
  • CPI manages modern protocols, security, governance.
  • No custom code burden in ECC
  • Easy S/4HANA migration path

Strategic Guidance:

  • Use CPI for protocol translation.
  • Keep ECC focused on business processes.
  • Plan your S/4HANA path.

3. SAP S/4HANA ON-PREMISE INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

S/4HANA builds on everything ECC provides and adds modern integration capabilities that change the game.

3.1 EVERYTHING ECC HAS, ENHANCED

RFCs/BAPIs:

  • All ECC BAPIs available
  • New S/4HANA-specific BAPIs
  • Better performance (HANA database)
  • CDS view consumption via RFCs

IDocs:

  • All ECC IDoc types
  • Improved processing speed
  • Better error handling
  • Enhanced monitoring

SOAP Services:

  • All enterprise services
  • Service adaptation framework
  • Better performance

3.2 ODATA SERVICES (THE GAME CHANGER)

OData is the REST-based protocol that makes SAP data accessible like modern APIs. This is what S/4HANA has that ECC doesn't, and it's transformative.OData introduces true RESTful APIs, designed for:

  • Web applications
  • Mobile apps
  • External developer consumption
  • Real-time queries

Why OData Matters

  • REST over HTTP
  • JSON-first
  • Queryable data access
  • Self-describing APIs

Key Characteristics:

  • RESTful: Standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)
  • JSON/XML: Modern data formats
  • Query-capable: $filter, $select, $expand, $orderby, $top, $skip
  • Self-documenting: $metadata endpoint
  • Stateless: No session management needed

SAP Gateway Architecture:

 

Standard S/4HANA APIs (Examples):

API Service

Business Purpose

Key Entity Sets

API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV

Purchase Order lifecycle management

A_PurchaseOrder, A_PurchaseOrderItem

API_PRODUCT_SRV

Material / Product master data

A_Product, A_ProductDescription

API_SALES_ORDER_SRV

A_SalesOrder, A_SalesOrderItem

API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV

  • Service Registration: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE
  • Testing: /IWFND/GW_CLIENT
  • Development: SEGW (Gateway Service Builder)
  • Monitoring: /IWFND/ERROR_LOG

OData Query Capabilities

Basic Read

GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseOrder

Filtering

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$filter=DocumentDate ge datetime'2025-01-01'

 and PurchaseOrderType eq 'NB'

Selecting Specific Fields

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$select=PurchaseOrder,Supplier,DocumentDate,TotalAmount

Expanding Navigation Properties

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder('4500000001')

?$expand=to_PurchaseOrderItem

Pagination

Response:

"__next": "...&$skiptoken=100"

Metadata Discovery
